reviewText: Artist Victor Clare (Mike Raven) is wowing the art world w/ his full-sized bronze sculptures of beautiful nude women. One art-lover even breaks into a gallery in an attempt to steal Victor's latest masterwork! He winds up being murdered for his efforts. The gallery owner, John Davis, decides to visit Victor's home / studio in order to secure further sculptures. Once there, he discovers a fractured family w/ many problems and many more secrets. Predictably, many deaths ensue. Victor's family members are quite interesting, including his sniveling, drunken son (Ronald Lacey- THE FEARLESS VAMPIRE KILLERS, RAIDERS OF THE LOST ARK), and his childlike, mentally disturbed wife. Among the visitors staying at Victor's homestead, there are several lovely young lasses! Unfortunately, they've caught Victor's eye. Will anyone survive the weekend? If you are a fan of slow-building horror stories populated by odd characters, accentuated w/ mystery, murder, and a touch of the supernatural, then you'll enjoy CRUCIBLE OF TERROR...
summary: "I'll Respect You When You Stop Making Me Sick!"...
Title: N/A

reviewText: CRUCIBLE OF TERROR is perhaps more notable for its lead actor's ties to the occult than for the film, itself. In it, a mad sculptor attempts to transubstantiate the souls of the dead into the bodies of the living using an ancient form of magic. Radio DJ Mike Raven plays the eccentric artist Victor Clare, with an overstated performance that is far too silly to even be mistaken as camp. His ultimate goal in transferring souls is never fully realized nor explained at any point throughout the film. A seemingly uncorrelated slasher element is also added to the meandering plot in an attempt to keep up the pace, but the preposterous murders, the ease with which the other characters dismiss them, and the poorly constructed reveal in the end make little sense at all. Ted Hooker's confused take on the basic HOUSE OF WAX premise inevitably fails to shock, frighten, or disturb, and can only be enjoyed for its brief moments of gore and unintentionally humor in an otherwise unforgivable production.-Carl ManesI Like Horror Movies
Title: N/A

reviewText: During the late 1960s & early 1970s, a number of small film companies set up shop in competition with Hammer and Amicus for a slice of the British horror film pie. The most successful of these was Tigon. THE SORCERERS, WITCHFINDER GENERAL, BLOOD ON SATAN'S CLAW, and CREEPING FLESH are all now classics of the genre. But there were other companies as well who lasted for only 2 or 3 films. Titan (INCENSE FOR THE DAMNED aka BLOODSUCKERS, and CORRUPTION), Tyburn (LEGEND OF THE WEREWOLF, THE GHOUL, and PERSECUTION), and Glendale (THE ASPHYX, CRUCIBLE OF TERROR). None of these films are considered classics but a number of them are of more than passing interest especially the 2 Glendale movies. I have already reviewed THE ASPHYX (which I DO consider a classic) and now I cast my eye on CRUCIBLE OF TERROR which, on my latest viewing of a quality  print (this DVD), shows itself to be movie of a lot more substance than I originally thought.On the surface CRUCIBLE is a reworking of Vincent Price's HOUSE OF WAX, two low budget AIP films, BUCKET OF BLOOD & BLOOD BATH, and a Flemish film known as MILL OF THE STONE WOMEN. The story of a mad artist (Mike Raven) who encases women's bodies in molten metal has a number of elements not found in the other titles. One of them is the bleak domestic situations of several of the characters. Then there's the occult element of the transference of dead souls into the living. Lastly there's the mystery element of who the murderer is since it's not the artist. In this new DVD release from Severin Films, not only is key missing footage restored, but the print is first rate and shows off cameraman Peter Newbrook's skill as as a cinematographer (he would direct THE ASPHYX right after this). CRUCIBLE OF TERROR isn't a great film but there are some inspired moments thanks to a solid sense of visual composition and some pretty gruesome murders. Lovers of classic British horror cinema will enjoy it more than others.
summary: Oddball Film Has Moments Of Inspiration

reviewText: Watched the whole thing because it seemed to be going somewhere in spite of some flaws.  But I was wrong.  Mark Twain once wrote a story wherein he had to kill everybody at the end because he said he couldn't figure out how to bring the plot to a conclusion.  This movie is similar in that the story introduces, in the last ten minutes, a major plot element that wasn't sufficiently developed throughout the movie in order to bring the story to a close.  The rest of the movie was as awkward and disjointed as my last sentence.
Title: N/A
